results.title: Piaf
results.creator_credit: Gary Halvorson, Bill Siegler, CBS, Fox Video and Franco London Film (Paris)
results.brief_description: This feature length filmed Broadway production (made for television) of Pam Gem’s play “Piaf” captures the very essence of the extraordinary and much-loved French singer, Edith Piaf. Jane Lapotaire won a Tony Award for Best Dramatic Actress in her role as Piaf and her portrayal of Piaf’s chaotic and emotion-charged life is inspirational. Lapotaire is ably supported by Zoe Wanamaker as Toine, David Leary as the Emcee/Manager, Judith Ivey as Madeleine and Peter Friedman as “Papa” Leplee. Cast also includes Nicholas Woodeson, Stephen Davies, Lewis Arlt and Robert Christian. Produced on Broadway by Elizabeth I. McCann, Nelle Nugent, the Schubert Organization, Ray Larsen in association with Warner Theatre Productions and directed for the stage by Howard Davies.

results.title: Pi - the movie. Blind rage
results.creator_credit: Darren Aronofsky, Eric Watson, Harvest Film Works, Plantain Films and Truth and Soul Pictures
results.brief_description: Max Cohen (Sean Gullette) is a brilliant Jewish mathematician who has spent ten years of his life attempting to uncover the numerical pattern underlying the ordered chaos of the stock market. Max, who faces near-madness because of recurring debilitating seizures, finds himself mysteriously pursued by a Wall Street financier, and by a Hassidic Jewish group who believe that his mathematical work will assist them bring about the Messianic Age as ordained by the mysteries of the Cabalah. As he comes close to understanding chaos, Max finds his life and the very nature of his existence threatened by both the profanity of the capitalists and the sacred intentions of the Jewish Cabalistic cult. “Pi” owes a great debt the fevered imaginative writing of the Czech-Jewish writer, Franz Kafka. Just as in Kafka the madness of the individual cannot be separated from the madness of the world around him, so in “Pi”, Max’s fear of insanity is made more unbearable by the urban bleakness of New York City. The filmmakers also owe a debt to the existential visual and aural pioneering work of David Lynch: the stark black and white cinematography and the acidic techno score by Clint Mansell wonderfully accentuate the hallucinogenic intensity of the film. Philosophical, technically brilliant and economical in both execution and length, “Pi” is movie that explores one of the pivotal questions of contemporary human existence: are sacred and scientific aspirations completely antithetical? For all the dark intensity of the themes, “Pi” emerges as a strangely hopeful film. The short Australian horror film, “Blind Rage” screens before “Pi”. The short is directed Clayton Jacobson and Cameron Mellor and produced by Rohan Timlock.

results.title: Physics: an interactive approach
results.creator_credit: Jacques Parent, Gilles Boivin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film demonstrates how the study of physics improves when students have the opportunity to work out the problems actively. Shown is a classroom-turned-laboratory, where films or film loops permit experiments to be staged on screen under control of the students. By starting or stopping films at will, any particular image or development can be measured on the screen and plotted on the students’ work sheets. Simple equipment for physics experiments is also shown.

results.title: Physical fitness and good health
results.creator_credit: Les Clark, Ken Peterson and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Uses animation to hows how exercise helps build muscle tissue and increase the capillaries’ capacity to supply blood to body parts; presents live action sequences of animals to show that rest is essential to all forms of animal life; discusses the importance of a proper diet for physical fitness and good health.

results.title: Photosynthesis. - 2nd ed.
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Shows how the application of the scientific method has revealed the mechanism by which green plants transform light energy into food. Controlled experiments test the photosynthesis process and shows how each components - light, carbon dioxide, water, and chloroplasts is essential. Also introduces several advanced concepts, such as the formation of intermediate compounds and the effect of different types of light.

results.title: Photography: an introduction
results.creator_credit: Michael Hollander, ABC-TV (Australia) and Coast Telecourses USA
results.brief_description: This series forms part of an Open Learning Unit offered by RMIT. It presents the technical principles of photography, the mechanics of the camera, the chemicals and physical reactions which produce a permanent image, the uses of various kinds of photographic equipment and techniques for producing better quality photographs.

results.title: Photography in science
results.creator_credit: Michael Hollander, ABC-TV (Australia) and Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Photography: an introduction”.
Overviews the wide variety of applications for scientific photography from providing legal evidence to diagnosing diseases. It is used to document, measure, reveal and communicate. Advances in computer and digital technology are revolutionising scientific photography and some of these changes are explained.

results.title: Studio and Location
results.creator_credit: Michael Hollander, ABC-TV (Australia) and Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Photography: an introduction”.
Profiles three Australian photographers - Jacqui Henshaw, Adrian Van Valen and John Gollings. Concentrating on fashion, architectural and car photography, they discuss the differences between shooting on location and in the studio with each context having its own advantages and limitations.

results.title: Photography around us
results.creator_credit: Michael Hollander, ABC-TV (Australia) and Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Photography: an introduction”.
Offers an introduction to the history of photography in Australia and its gradual acceptance as an artform by museums and educational institutions. Local authorities in the field discuss changing attitudes to photography. In particular Sue Fereday, Director of the Centre for Contemporary Photography, and Isobel Crombie, Curator of Photography at the National Gallery of Victoria explain their policies towards collecting and exhibiting photography.
